value: Location of Peng Chau in Hong Kong

Peng Chau  has a reputation for being dull and lacking in tourist attractions. Yet, if you go there expecting to see very little, you maybe pleasantly surprised. Restaurants here are cheaper than the other islands and you get the feeling you are off the 'beaten-track' of mass tourism. Perhaps it is the place to go at the end of your holiday when you are weary of the fast-pace of the big city and just want to slow down, have a drink and chat with friends. From Peng Chau you can easily take the dilapidated ferry over to the Trappist monastery on
island and walk, for a couple of hours, along the hilly footpath to Mui Wo. From Mui Wo you can take another ferry back to
island. It is located 8 km to the west of Hong Kong Island. The size of the island is 1km square. Peng Chau, as the name suggests, is mostly flat land.
Most people take the ferry service from

Pier 6 - next to the Central Star Ferry. The fast ferry service takes around 25 minutes and cost $26.80, while the slower ferry takes 50 minutes and costs $14.40. 

Alternatively you can arrive by boat from Discovery Bay on
island (which is very close). The Inter Islands ferry provides 10 sailings a day between Mui Wo and Peng Chau.
There are no cars, buses or taxis on the island - that is the attraction. Visitors can hire bicycles at reasonable prices.

value: The island has eight temples, including a Tin Hau temple dating back to 1792 which houses a whale rib. Outside the Tin Hau Temple there is a stone monument warning about pirates. Finger Hill has views of Disneyland and the Tsing Ma Bridge. Peng Chau still retains 60% of its natural seashore. Around the coast there is a diversity of marine life, including Chinese White dolphins. The island is surrounded by some of Hong Kong's few remaining coral reefs.

Most tourists come to Peng Chau to walk around this car-free island. The island has many footpaths that you can safely explore. 
Head for Finger Hill which is popular for it panoramic views of the island. 
Don't miss the beach at Tung Wan, from there you can head north through the small farms until you reach the north shore of the island. The walk along the northern stretch of coastline is less well-known and takes you past a couple of small beaches that are popular with swimmers and sunbathers.

Peng Chau is a good place to buy souvenir Chinese ceramics. There is a workshop and studio that makes various items. Another shop (not far from HSBC) sells hand painted ceramics such as plates and Chinese teapots. You can also try your hand at painting your own.

Choices of places to eat on the island are fairly limited if you don't speak Cantonese. Most eateries are small and sell traditional food aimed at local people. There are two Thai restaurants that are popular with tourists because they speak English and provide English menus.

The north end of Tung Wan beach has BBQ pits.
In the main square, opposite the Wellcome supermarket is a French-style cafe-bar. Here you can sit outside and drink wine and coffee. Beer is sold in some of the larger restaurants and cafes.
Peng Chau does not have any official hotels or guest houses. There are no government campsites.
